data.title: Who Brandon Miller can join as Nashville area first-round NBA draft picks from James Wiseman to Ron Mercer
data.meta_description: Twelve Nashville-area high school stars have gone in the first round of the NBA Draft since 1994. Brandon Miller is poised to become the 13th.
data.text:
Former Cane Ridge and Alabama basketball star Brandon Miller is likely to be chosen among the first five picks of the 2023 NBA Draft, which will take place starting at 7 p.m. Thursday at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

Miller would become the 13th Nashville area high school star in the last 30 years to be selected in the first round. Here's a look at the previous 12, arranged in order of what number they were drafted from highest to lowest in the opening round:

James Wiseman

Year drafted: 2020 (No. 2) by the Golden State Warriors

High school: Ensworth (transferred to Memphis East after sophomore season)

College: Memphis

NBA career: Wiseman started 27 games as a rookie before tearing his meniscus in April 2021. As a result, he missed the entirety of the Warriors' 2022 championship run. Wiseman struggled to earn his way back into the rotation last season and was traded to Detroit in February, averaging 12.7 points and 8.1 rebounds as the Pistons' starting center.

Darius Garland

Year drafted: 2019 (No. 5) by the Cleveland Cavaliers

High school: Brentwood Academy

College: Vanderbilt

NBA career: Garland has steadily improved over his four seasons in Cleveland. In 2022, his third season, Garland made his first All-Star team and finished third overall in the Most Improved Player voting. The point guard averaged 21.6 points and 7.8 assists last season to help guide the Cavaliers to the playoffs.

Ron Mercer

Year drafted: 1997 (No. 6) by the Boston Celtics

High school: Goodpasture (transferred to Oak Hill Academy after junior season)

College: Kentucky

NBA career: Mercer made the All-Rookie first team in 1998 and averaged 13.6 points per game during his eight-season career. He bounced around frequently, suiting up for seven different teams, most notably the Celtics and Bulls.

Corey Brewer

Year drafted: 2007 (No. 7) by the Minnesota Timberwolves

High school: Portland

College: Florida

NBA career: Brewer played for eight teams during a career that lasted from 2007 to 2020, averaging 8.7 points per game. He started 310 games during his career, the bulk of them coming during two stints with the Timberwolves, and had a 51-point game in 2014 during that second stint.

Brandan Wright

Year drafted: 2007 (No. 8) by the Charlotte Bobcats

High school: Brentwood Academy

College: North Carolina

NBA career: The 6-10 big man was a journeyman throughout his decade-long NBA career, playing for seven different teams. His most successful stretch came with the Mavericks, where he averaged 8.3 points and 4.0 rebounds in 198 games between 2011 to 2015.

Shawn Marion

Year drafted: 1999 (No. 9) by the Phoenix Suns

High school: Clarksville

College: UNLV

NBA career: Marion was one of the most dynamic forwards in the league during his 16-season career, averaging 15.2 points and 8.7 rebounds per game. He made four All-Star teams with the Suns and won an NBA championship with the Mavericks in 2011.

Marcus Haislip

Year drafted: 2002 (No. 13) by the Milwaukee Bucks

High school: Marshall County

College: Tennessee

NBA career: The 6-foot-10 center appeared in just 89 NBA games, averaging 3.5 points. He had more success overseas, carving out a 15-year career in Europe, Asia and Africa.

Keon Johnson

Year drafted: 2021 (No. 21) by the New York Knicks

High school: Webb School -Bell Buckle

College: Tennessee

NBA career: The Knicks traded Johnson to the Clippers on draft night, but he played just 15 games in Los Angeles before being traded to Portland in February 2022. He's averaged 6.5 points in 62 games with the Trail Blazers.

Dontae' Jones

Year drafted: 1996 (No. 21) by the New York Knicks

High school: Stratford

College: Mississippi State

NBA career: Jones averaged 2.9 points in 15 games with the Celtics during the 1997-98 season, his only one in the NBA. He then played a decade internationally and led the Chinese Basketball Association in scoring in 2008.

MORE: The facts of Brandon Miller's actions on Jan. 15 from video, testimony about fatal shooting

John Jenkins

Year drafted: 2012 (No. 23) by the Atlanta Hawks

High school: Station Camp

College: Vanderbilt

NBA career: Jenkins spent the first three seasons of his career with the Hawks, averaging 5.6 points, but has since bounced around between the NBA, the G League and overseas.

David Vaughn III

Year drafted: 1995 (No. 25) by the Orlando Magic

High school: Whites Creek

College: Memphis

NBA career: The son of former Cameron star David Vaughn Jr. played in 118 NBA games between 1995 and 1999, averaging 2.9 points and 3.1 rebounds.

MORE: Who are the greatest Nashville area high school boys basketball players of all time?

David Harrison

Year drafted: 2004 (No. 29) by the Indiana Pacers

High school: Brentwood Academy

College: Colorado

NBA career: Harrison played all 189 games of his NBA career with the team that drafted him. The center averaged 5.0 points and 2.9 rebounds over four seasons in Indiana.

Jacob Shames can be reached by email at jshames@gannett.com and on Twitter @Jacob_Shames.
